creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund
description: S-shaped path in an abstracted landscape; greens; pinks in foreground, LLQ; rust-oranges in spots scattered throughout; pinkish-orange sky
inscription:
Mark, Inscription and Label

Inscribed at lower center of millboard mount, in pen and brown ink: Bas
markings:
Degas\' estate stamp, LLC, in red: [Degas]

on back of mount on label: [V. A. D. 4 / No. 42] (abbreviation of \"Vente Atelier Degas, 4th Sale\"); inscribed in white chalk: [42] (lot number in atelier sale); in blue pencil: [ph 2310] (sale price); framer\'s label [ADAM DUPRÉ / 19bis, Rue Fontaine PARIS]; white label with blue border: [N.o 34]
medium: Oil monotype and pastel on heavy paper; laid down on paper-wrapped millboard
provenance: Estate of the artist, Lugt 658 (until 1919; his sale, 4th sale, Galerie Georges Petit, Paris, July 2-4, 1919, no. 42, for Fr 2,310, to Cottevieille); Collection Cottevieille, Paris. Sale, Hôtel George V, Paris, June 18, 1974, no. 1. Private collection, Paris. [C.G. Boerner, New York, and Galerie Terrades, Paris, by 2008-9; sold to MIA]
text:
Edgar Degas devoted his artistic career to breaking boundaries. Winding River is simultaneously a landscape and an abstraction. It is a painting, a print, and a drawing. Colorful and poetic, it recalls Impressionism but was certainly not painted directly from nature.

In 1890, Degas embarked on a series of nearly fifty landscape monotypes—prints made by painting in dilute oils on a smooth copper plate and then transferring the image to a sheet of paper, using a printing press. Degas, it seems, could never leave an artwork alone. As with many of his monotypes, after printing this one he overworked the image (now reversed) with pastel crayons.

Rather than recording impressions of nature’s beauty outdoors, Degas worked indoors, relying on imagination and perhaps also memory. Winding River is loosely based on a Japanese color print made in 1856 by Utagawa Hiroshige, whose work Degas collected. That Degas worked on the image both before and after printing distances it from the immediacy of true Impressionism.
title: Winding River
